description: From Middle English *mishaven, from Old English *mishabban, attested in derivative mishabbende (“having ill”), equivalent to mis- +‎ have.

verbs.description: mishave (third-person singular simple present mishaves, present participle mishaving, simple past and past participle mishaved)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, reflexive, obsolete) To misbehave or misconduct (oneself); do wrong.
examples: It is agreed  […]  that if anie servaunte  […]  shall by fighting, quarrelling or other unsemelie maner at anie time herafter misdemeane or mishave himself and therof be ones monished or warned  […]
